awd_titl_txt: Digitization TCN: Collaborative Research: Building a global consortium of bryophytes and lichens: keystones of cryptobiotic communities.
awd_abstract_narration:
This collaborative project comprised of ten awards will integrate information about bryophytes and lichens, with each other and with their commensal organisms, including fungi, on a worldwide scale. Bryophytes and lichens are functionally related as the main hosts for cryptobiotic communities forming minute "forests" that provide a matrix of habitats for many microscopic organisms, including tardigrades, mites, rotifers, micro-mollusks, microalgae, microfungi, and prokaryotes. These communities have global relevance and perform essential functions on our planet, for example, the biological soil crusts that harbor these communities form a "living skin" covering approximately 12% of  Earth's terrestrial surface.  In addition, professional training will be provided for a large number of undergraduates, with a focus on leveraging local resources to promote underrepresented students in STEM fields.  Students will be trained in digitization and collections management, and will contribute to the education and public outreach components of the project. 

Through this collaboration, twenty-five US herbaria will image and digitize associated metadata for almost 1.2 million bryophyte and lichen herbarium specimens held in US institutions. Imaging the physical specimens of these organisms and integrating data from comparative genomics, nucleotide sequence data, and other resources is unprecedented on this scale. These integrated data will form a critical resource for evolutionary and ecological studies, that may, in turn, lead to a deeper understanding of (1) how biocrusts perform their ecosystem functions, (2) the roles of bryophytes and lichens in carbon/nitrogen cycling, (3) the dynamic evolution of symbioses in space and time, (4) the historical and contemporary drivers of endophyte co-diversification, and (5) the evolution of biodiversity using spatial phylogenetics. Deep-learning approaches using repurposed digital images may also provide powerful new investigative tools.  Digitized data will be shared with iDigBio.org and other repositories.  A multi-pronged approach to broader impacts spans from K-12 to participatory citizen science initiatives.  These include (1) diverse digital, interactive, and object-based learning outreach programs; (2) online lesson plans; (3) science youth groups; (4) Science Clubs and public educator workshops; and (5) a series of videos using Learning Glass – which collapses the perspectives of viewer and presenter into one shared perspective. In addition, the PIs and collaborating institutions will host WeDigBio and K-12 clubs hosting label transcription crowdsourcing events during the award period. The project also partners with Zooniverse, leaders in online citizen science, where we will develop an online platform for citizen scientists to make observations on character traits that can then enhance metadata not always on the scientific label data.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Lichens and bryophytes are relatively small, unrelated organisms that occur throughout the world in wetlands, forests, deserts, and savannas predominately on rocks and soil. They are dominant organisms in arctic, alpine, and desert habitats, which serve as early indicators for climate change, and cover approximately 12% of the planet’s terrestrial surface. Lichens and bryophytes provide a habitat for many microscopic organisms such as water bears, mites, rotifers, micro-mollusks, microalgae, microfungi, and prokaryotes. In addition, an enormous amount of species‐rich life including algal/bacterial symbionts and internal fungi occur within lichens and bryophytes. Over 67% of the world’s carbon is stored by bryophytes in peat bogs and both lichens and bryophytes are used extensively in environmental monitoring for metal and radioactive deposition and air pollution monitoring. The major goal of this overall project, TCN Digitization: Building a Global Consortium of Bryophytes and Lichens: Keystones of Cryptobiotic Communities (GLOBAL), was to image nearly 1.2 million non-North American specimens of bryophytes and lichens held in U.S. herbaria along with their associated metadata. These synthesized data will form the foundation for answering a wide variety of evolutionary and ecological studies, including novel insights into multi-species symbioses, a deeper understanding of how biocrusts function, and fulfilling knowledge gaps in bryophyte-associated nitrogen fixation and bryophytes-microarthropod interactions. This project also trained students in image capture and processing, digitization, databasing, and collections management, and contributed to numerous education and public outreach events.

The contributions of University of Illinois (ILL, ILLS), Louisiana State University (LSU), University of Michigan (MICH), and University of Minnesota (MIN) were the imaging of 91,719 bryophytes and 47,743 lichens. In additional, specimen metadata were databased for 75,556 bryophytes and 42,208 lichens. We successfully trained 16 students, 13 technicians, and 4 volunteers in herbarium and database management, imaging, and digitization techniques giving them hands-on experience working with collections and their digital derivatives. This training is crucial for creating the expertise needed to sustain the specimen digitization effort and for educating the next generation of aspiring natural history collections specialists. Collections staff at our four institutions expanded their skills in digitization project management and curation of physical and digital collections. A custom data toolkit was developed for DNA sequence data exports for GenBank submissions, taxa and collection record reporting for individual collections, drag and drop image file upload and transfer, and automated seven day cycling of collection data backup. The Taxonomic Reporting tool has been effective in contributing to the addition of over 5000 new and updated taxonomic associations. The GenBank metadata tool has assisted in the addition of over 2000 new genetic associations with specimen data, while the file upload component has transferred over 15,000 images and over 6000 taxonomic associations were updated. All data is served on the Lichen Portal (http://lichenportal.org) and the Bryophyte Portal (http://bryophyteportal.org) where it is freely available to a diverse group of stakeholders including the general public, educators and students, and regional and national agencies charged with managing natural resources.
